raw_text:
Immigration to be election issue
 
 Immigration and asylum have normally been issues politicians from the big parties have tiptoed around at election time.
 
 But no longer. Both Labour and the Tories have signalled their intention of making them central to their election campaigns. They have been struck by the level of concern amongst voters about the issues, with internal surveys showing they have the potential to swing large numbers of votes. That was also true at the last general election and the issue did briefly become a campaigning issue. But it sparked the probably predictable furore with claims politicians were either stoking up xenophobia or, alternatively, running scared of addressing the problem. But this time around it looks set to be one of the core battlegrounds with both the big parties competing to set out tough policies.
 
 The Tories are already committed to imposing annual limits on immigration, with a quota for asylum seekers and with applications processed outside the UK. Labour has already branded the proposal unworkable but party strategists have seen the Tories seizing a poll advantage over the issue.
 
 Now Home Secretary Charles Clarke has come up with alternative proposals for a points system to ensure only immigrants who can benefit the economy will be granted entry, and to kick out more failed asylum seekers. That has been attacked by the Tories as too little, too late and for failing to tackle the key issue of the numbers entering the UK. The Liberal Democrats have not been drawn too deeply into the argument but have called for a Europe-wide policy on immigration.
 
 But, while all the parties appear to agree the time has come to properly debate and address the issue, there are already signs they will run into precisely the same problems as before. Former union leader Sir Bill Morris has already accused both the big parties of engaging in a "bidding war about who can be nastiest to asylum seekers".
 
 "My concern is that, whilst the Labour Party and the Conservative Party will take a constructive approach to the debate, right-wing political parties, picking up on statements like `burden to Britain' will exploit this and create a lot of fear and uncertainty". It is precisely that concern - and the possible suggestion the issue is playing to the far right's racist agenda - that will provoke strong reactions from many concerned with this issue. The challenge for the big parties is to ensure they can engage in the debate during the cut and thrust of a general election while also avoiding that trap.
llama3.2:1b: Immigration and asylum have become central issues in the 2023 UK general election campaign, sparking concerns among voters about xenophobia and economic benefits.
Both Labour and the Conservatives have proposed policies to address these concerns.
The Tories' proposals include an annual points system for immigrants who can benefit the economy, while Labour has criticized them as unworkable.
Home Secretary Charles Clarke's alternative proposal of a points system has been attacked by the Tories as too little, too late.
The Liberal Democrats and former union leader Sir Bill Morris have called for a Europe-wide policy on immigration.
The issue is likely to be a battleground in the election campaign, with right-wing parties potentially exploiting concerns about asylum seekers to create fear and uncertainty.
llama3.2:3b: Immigration to become central issue in UK election, both Labour and Tories signal tougher policies, despite concerns about xenophobia and the potential for a "bidding war" among parties, with Liberal Democrats calling for a Europe-wide policy, and former union leader Sir Bill Morris warning of exploitation by right-wing parties.
gemma2:2b: Immigration is becoming a central campaign issue for Labour and Conservative parties ahead of an upcoming election.
Both parties are planning to adopt tough immigration policies, but there's disagreement on the specifics.
The Conservative party has proposed limits on immigration, asylum processing changes, and points system to prioritize economic benefits.
Liberal Democrats call for a European-wide policy on immigration.
A key concern is that right-wing parties may exploit the debate to stoke xenophobic sentiments, leading to backlash from those who are concerned about immigration.
The challenge for all parties is to engage in this debate without fueling fears and division, while navigating the political pressure of a general election.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
The key points about immigration being a new election issue are:

- Both Labour and Tory candidates have indicated their intention to make immigration and asylum an important part of their campaigns.
- Voters are concerned about the potential for large numbers of immigrants entering Britain, with estimates showing it could sway up to 80% of voters.
- This is not yet a major electoral priority, but politicians face increased pressure from both parties due to its importance in general elections.

The text also discusses the current state of immigration policy and some proposed solutions:

- The Conservatives have introduced an annual limit on immigration, with a quota for asylum seekers and applications processed outside the UK.
- Labour has already branded their proposal "unworkable," but it is seen as a potential solution to the issue.
- Charles Clarke proposes a points-based system to ensure only immigrants who benefit the economy are granted entry, while rejecting criticism from both the Tories and the Liberal Democrats.
- Sir Bill Morris accuses both parties of engaging in an "bidding war" about who can be nasty to asylum seekers.
- The big parties will engage in the debate during general elections but need to avoid a vote-trap situation.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Immigration and asylum are becoming key issues in upcoming elections, leading both major parties to emphasize them heavily.
While concerns about these issues rose at previous elections, this time could be decisive with both sides competing on policy solutions.
The Conservatives propose annual immigration limits and alternative points-based systems, while Labour criticizes the plan as impractical.
Both parties acknowledge it's a pivotal moment for debate but worry they'll meet resistance from more extreme groups like the far-right.
qwen2.5:3b: Immigration and asylum have become central issues in upcoming elections, driven by voter concerns.
Both Labour and the Tories intend to use these issues as key campaign points.
The Tories propose annual immigration limits, asylum quotas processed outside UK, and applying for entry only those who can benefit the economy.
Home Secretary Charles Clarke suggests a points system instead.
While all parties agree it's time to debate openly, former union leader Sir Bill Morris warns both major parties could exploit the issue, possibly playing into far-right racist agendas.
The challenge lies in engaging on these issues without exacerbating fear and uncertainty.
opencoder:1.5b:
Immigration and Asylum Issues: A Central Issue of National ELECTIONS

The Tories have expressed their intention on making immigration policies more inclusive, with an emphasis on granting asylum seekers who are currently unable to return to the UK due to family restrictions or other similar circumstances.
They also stressed the potential increase in voter turnout by allowing a larger number of votes.
Labour, however, has already committed to imposing annual limits on the quota for asylum applications and allows applications processed outside the UK.
The Tories have also raised concerns over their proposal being too cautious and failing to address the issue effectively.

Home Secretary Charles Clarke, along with other party strategists, has proposed alternative policies to balance the points system against a broader range of reasons, including an increased burden on the country and wider societal expectations about equality in return for asylum.
The parties have also taken steps to create arguments that could provoke strong reactions.
The former group, known as the 'bidding war', has attacked statements like "burden to Britain" suggesting a higher cost of returning to the UK compared to when they arrived from another country.
However, despite these attempts, it is clear that this issue continues to be central to national elections and needs regular discussion and addressing.
The concerns raised by voters and concerned citizens are integral to the issue's ongoing challenges.

The summary should include key ideas, such as:
- Immigration and asylum have normally been issues politicians from the big parties have tiptoed around at election time.
Both Labour and the Tories have signalled their intention of making them central to their election campaigns.
- They have been struck by the level of concern amongst voters about the issue, with internal surveys showing they have the potential to swing large numbers of votes.
- That was also true at the last general election and the issue did briefly become a campaigning issue.
- But it sparked the probably predictable furore with claims politicians were either stoking up xenophobia or, conversely, running scared of addressing the problem.
- But this time around it looks set to be one of the core battlegrounds with both the big parties competing to set out tough policies.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Immigration to be an election issue  
 Immigration has become a critical battleground for both the Labour Party and the Conservative Party.
Both are now pushing hard to win their seats during the upcoming general election, driven by concerns about voter uncertainty and the potential to shift significant numbers of votes.
This marks a significant shift from previous years, where voters were cautious due to fears about issues like xenophobia or lack of political traction.
Now, both parties aim to address this crisis through a points system that filters out non-immigrants while allowing only those who can benefit economically to enter the UK.
Sir Bill Morris has also criticized the big parties for using terms like 'burden to Britain' to exploit voter concerns.
tinyllama:1.1b: The election campaigns of both the Labour Party and the Conservative Party have seen them take a position on the issue of immigration and asylum, with internal surveys revealing that they are likely to be key issues for vote-catching.

However, despite their commitment to policies, both parties are expected to engage in a bidding war over how to address the problem, with the Conservatives seen by many as exploiting the issue to appeal to right-wing political parties picking up on statements suggesting that the issue is being used to target British workers.
As such, there will be strong reactions from concerned individuals and organizations who are worried about the levels of xenophobia or the government's policy on handling asylum seekers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: This text describes an assumption about the nature of the relationship between immigration and asylum, which is why it seems incomplete.

However, I can provide you with some key points:

1.
Immigration has always been a subject of significant concern for politicians from both major parties during election campaigns.
Both Labour and the Conservatives have made immigration an issue central to their election campaigns.
Recent polls suggest that the level of concern amongst voters about immigration is at its highest point since the last general election.
This has prompted both parties to make it a key election battleground.

The Conservatives have proposed imposing annual limits on immigration, while the Labour Party has suggested a points-based system that would prioritize economic benefits and selectively grant more entry to certain groups.

However, there are concerns about the potential impact of these policies on immigrants who have already entered the UK, as well as a backlash from those concerned with the numbers entering the country.
Both parties believe they can address this issue during the upcoming election by focusing on ensuring only immigrants who can benefit the economy are admitted into the UK.

However, there may also be a risk of exploiting emotions and fears related to immigration for political gain, particularly among right-wing political parties who have been criticized for not tackling the issue effectively.
phi:2.7b: The text discusses how immigration and asylum have become significant issues in upcoming elections for both Labour and the Conservative parties, despite them being topics often avoided in past campaigns.

Both parties are committed to implementing tough policies related to immigration, with the Tories already committed to annual limits on immigration and quotas for asylum seekers, while Labour has branded the proposal unworkable but still planning to address the issue.

The Liberal Democrats have called for a Europe-wide policy on immigration, but there are concerns that both parties will fall into a "bidding war" about who can be nastiest to asylum seekers, potentially creating fear and uncertainty in voters.
The challenge for the big parties is to engage in the debate during an election while avoiding triggering strong reactions from those concerned with this issue.
orca-mini:3b: Immigration and asylum are set to become a core battleground in the upcoming general election, with both the Labour and Conservative parties competing to set out tough policies on the issue.
The Home Secretary has proposed a points system to limit immigration and kick out more failed asylum seekers, but this has been attacked as too little, too late.
Sir Bill Morris has accused both the big parties of engaging in a "bidding war about who can be nastiest to asylum seekers".
The issue is likely to provoke strong reactions from many concerned with racism.
hermes3:3b: Immigration becoming central election issue, both Labour and Tories aiming tough policies on asylum & immigration limits.

Despite parties agreeing to address the issue, concerns remain that right-wing political parties will exploit the topic for their own agenda.
The challenge for big parties is to engage in the debate during elections while avoiding this trap.

The Conservatives propose annual immigration limits and offshore asylum processing, while Labour counters with a points-based system to admit economically beneficial immigrants and deport more failed asylum seekers.
The Liberal Democrats advocate for a Europe-wide policy.
However, the debate risks fueling xenophobia, with critics warning that harsh rhetoric could be exploited by the far right.
The challenge for major parties is to engage in the discussion without inciting fear or division.

The big parties must ensure they can engage in the debate without fueling fear and uncertainty during an election season.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Both Labour and the Conservatives have decided to make immigration and asylum central issues in their upcoming election campaigns, citing voters' growing concern about these matters.
The Tories propose annual immigration limits and asylum quotants processed outside the UK, while Labour criticizes this as unworkable but acknowledges a poll advantage.
Home Secretary Charles Clarke suggests a points system to prioritize beneficial immigrants and deport failed asylum seekers, yet the Tories deem it insufficient.
The Liberal Democrats advocate for a unified European policy on immigration.
Despite agreement on debating the issue, concerns remain that the debate may exacerbate far-right sentiments due to potential exploitation by these parties.
The challenge for major parties is to engage in this critical discussion without contributing to racist agendas or fueling fear and uncertainty among voters.
